statement:
The union of a collection of closed subsets of a topological space need
not, of course, be closed. However, we do have the following result:

The union of a locally finite collection of closed subsets of a
topological space is itself closed.

Let $\cal S$ be a locally finite collection of closed subsets of a
topological space $X$, and put $Y=\cup\cal S$. Let $x\in X\setminus Y$.
By local finiteness there is an open neighbourhood $U$ of $x$ that meets
only finitely many members of $\cal S$, say $A_1,\dots,A_n$. So
$U\setminus Y=U\setminus\bigcup_{i=1}^n A_i$, which is open. Thus
$U\setminus Y$ is an open neighbourhood of $x$ that does not meet $Y$.
It follows that $Y$ is closed.

One use for this result can be found in the entry on gluing together
continuous functions.
names: the union of a locally finite collection of closed sets is closed
